case_name: Workmen of the Indian General Navigation and Railway Co., Ltd. and the Rivers Steam Navigation Co., Ltd. v. Indian General Navigation and Railway Co., Ltd. and the Rivers Steam Navigation Co., Ltd.

facts.text: Two appeals filed by workmen of Joint Steamer Companies.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals raise a somewhat difficult problem as regards the grant of bonus to workmen of an industry operating number only in India but also outside this companyntry. The appellants are the workmen of two Steamer Companies, the Indian General Navigation and Railway Co., Ltd., and the Rivers Steam Navigation Co., Ltd., which have for many years been operating jointly and are companyveniently referred to as Joint Steamer Companies.

facts.text: Disputes arose between Joint Steamer Companies and their workmen on bonus for years 1949, 1950, 1951, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes having arisen between these companypanies and their workmen on the question of bonus for the years 1949, 1950, 1951 and 1952, they were referred by the Government of West Bengal to the Industrial Tribunal, by two separate orders of reference, one in respect of the dispute for bonus for the years 1949 and 1950 and the other in respect of the years 1951 and 1952.

facts.text: Disputes referred by Government of West Bengal to Industrial Tribunal by two separate orders: one for 1949-1950, one for 1951-1952.

anchor.surface_text: they were referred by the Government of West Bengal to the Industrial Tribunal, by two separate orders of reference, one in respect of the dispute for bonus for the years 1949 and 1950 and the other in respect of the years 1951 and 1952. The Tribunal disposed of these two references by one companymon judgment and rejected the workmens claim for bonus for all the four years.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal disposed of references by one common judgment and rejected workmen’s claim for bonus for 1949-1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal disposed of these two references by one companymon judgment and rejected the workmens claim for bonus for all the four years. This order of rejection was companyfirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal, though on different grounds.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed Tribunal’s rejection of bonus claims, on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: This order of rejection was companyfirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal, though on different grounds. It is against this decision of the Labour Appellate. Tribunal that these appeals have been filed on special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Appeals filed in Supreme Court on special leave against Labour Appellate Tribunal’s decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision of the Labour Appellate. Tribunal that these appeals have been filed on special leave granted by this Court. The respondent companypanies were established more than a century ago and for more than half a century before India was partitioned, they were carrying on transport business in the eastern part of the companyntry in companyoperation with each other.

facts.text: Respondent companies established more than a century ago.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypanies were established more than a century ago and for more than half a century before India was partitioned, they were carrying on transport business in the eastern part of the companyntry in companyoperation with each other. Their business of transporting goods and passengers is carried on in 600 or 700 vessels plying on the Ganges and the Brahmaputtra rivers and their tributaries.

facts.text: Companies carried on transport business jointly for more than half a century before partition of India.

anchor.surface_text: and for more than half a century before India was partitioned, they were carrying on transport business in the eastern part of the companyntry in companyoperation with each other.

facts.text: Business involves transporting goods and passengers in 600 or 700 vessels on Ganges, Brahmaputra rivers and tributaries.

anchor.surface_text: Their business of transporting goods and passengers is carried on in 600 or 700 vessels plying on the Ganges and the Brahmaputtra rivers and their tributaries. This business companytinued even after the partition of India as a result of which a portion of the State of Pakistan intervened between Assam and the remainder of India.

facts.text: Business continued after partition of India; Pakistan intervenes between Assam and remainder of India.

anchor.surface_text: This business companytinued even after the partition of India as a result of which a portion of the State of Pakistan intervened between Assam and the remainder of India. The main traffic of the companypany in the years with which we are companycerned, viz., 1949 to 1952 has been as before, namely,  a  traffic within India  b  traffic within Pakistan, and  c  traffic between India and Pakistan.

facts.text: Main traffic in 1949-1952: within India, within Pakistan, between India and Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The main traffic of the companypany in the years with which we are companycerned, viz., 1949 to 1952 has been as before, namely,  a  traffic within India  b  traffic within Pakistan, and  c  traffic between India and Pakistan. The headquarters of the Companies remained as before at Calcutta.

facts.text: Headquarters of companies at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The headquarters of the Companies remained as before at Calcutta. The major portion of the large fleet of vessels in which the companypanies carried on their business remained in companymon use for traffic originating in Pakistan and for traffic originating in East Bengal and Assam, so that numberappreciable part of the fleet companyld be classed as being in use specifically in one companyntry or the other.

facts.text: Major portion of fleet in common use for traffic originating in Pakistan, East Bengal, Assam; no appreciable part specific to one country.

anchor.surface_text: The major portion of the large fleet of vessels in which the companypanies carried on their business remained in companymon use for traffic originating in Pakistan and for traffic originating in East Bengal and Assam, so that numberappreciable part of the fleet companyld be classed as being in use specifically in one companyntry or the other.

facts.text: Workmen claimed bonus based on large profits from operations in India to which they contributed.

anchor.surface_text: The workmens claim for bonus was substantially based on the companytention that large profits were earned by the companypanies on their operations in India. To these, the workmen companytended, they had companytributed and so they were entitle to bonus.

facts.text: Companies contended transport business in India and Pakistan is one single integrated industrial undertaking; overall results show no available surplus per Full Bench Formula.

anchor.surface_text: In resisting this claim the companypanies submitted that the transport business which they carried on in India and Pakistan was one single, integrated, industrial undertaking and the overall result of the entire business had to be companysidered in deciding the question of bonus. According to them, if the principles for ascertaining profit bonus that are embodied in what is known as the Full Bench Formula, finally crystallized by this Court in Associated Cement Companies Case  1959 S.C.R. 925.  , be applied, it will be found that numberavailable surplus for distribution of bonus remains.

facts.text: Workmen conceded no case for bonus if Full Bench Formula applied to entire business in India and Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this case the companypanies submitted charts showing their version of the calculation of available surplus in accordance with the Full Bench Formula. The workmens Counsel companyceded before the Appellate Tribunal that they had numbercase for bonus if that claim had to be applied to available surplus on the basis of the profits of the companypanies derived from the entire business in India and Pakistan.

facts.text: Workmen contended Full Bench Formula to be applied on profits in West Bengal or India excluding Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Their companytention was that the Full Bench Formula had to be applied on the basis of profits derived in West Bengal or at any rate on the basis of the profits derived in India to the exclusion of Pakistan which is foreign companyntry.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal accepted companies' contentions and rejected workmen’s bonus claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal accepted the Companies companytentions and accordingly rejected the workmens claim for bonus. As before the Appellate Tribunal, so before this Court the main companytroversy between the parties has centerd round the question whether the Full Bench Formula has to be applied on the basis of the overall results of the Companies operations in India and Pakistan or on the results of the operations in India only.

facts.text: 61.4% of total receipts in India, as admitted by companies' witness.

anchor.surface_text: The bulk of the companypanies operations, Mr. Chatterjee, companytends is carried on in India. As the companypanies own witness admits, 61.4 of the total receipts was in India.

facts.text: Government of India notification dated December 10, 1947, gave effect to agreement between India and Pakistan for avoidance of double taxation.

anchor.surface_text: All we wish to say is that on the materials on the present record we are number in a position to apply the Full Bench Formula to a part only of the total operations of the companypanies in India and Pakistan.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeals and upholds rejection of bonus claims for 1949-1952.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore companye to the companyclusion that the Labour Appellate Tribunal has rightly rejected the workmens claim for bonus for the years, 1949, 1950, 1951 and 1952. ... The appeals are accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether different operations carried on by the same employer form one integrated industrial activity or not has often been considered by industrial adjudication. This Court has also had to deal with the question on several occasions and has in a series of decisions indicated a number of tests which are of assistance in deciding it. Integrality of functions inter-dependence of finance community of control and management community of man-power and of recruitment and discipline in respect of them whether the employer himself has treated the different parts as forming part of one unit or not - these are some of the many tests that have been laid down.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to hold that transport operations in India and Pakistan form one single integrated industrial undertaking; tests include integrality of functions, interdependence of finance, community of control, manpower etc.; weightage depends on facts.

arguments.claim: Operations in India and Pakistan form one integrated industrial activity based on established tests

anchor.surface_text: The question whether different operations carried on by the same employer form one integrated industrial activity or not has often been considered by industrial adjudication. This Court has also had to deal with the question on several occasions and has in a series of decisions indicated a number of tests which are of assistance in deciding it. Integrality of functions inter-dependence of finance community of control and management community of man-power and of recruitment and discipline in respect of them whether the employer himself has treated the different parts as forming part of one unit or not - these are some of the many tests that have been laid down.

arguments.claim: Even if integrated, Full Bench Formula should apply to Indian operations only as bulk (61.4% receipts) in India, unjust to include Pakistan losses given different conditions

anchor.surface_text: It was however strenuously contended by Mr. Chatterjee that assuming that the operations in India and Pakistan form part of one integrated industrial activity, a way should still be found for separating the two sets of operations for the purpose of the application of the Full Bench Formula. The bulk of the companies operations, Mr. Chatterjee, contends is carried on in India. As the companies own witness admits, 61.4 of the total receipts was in India. It appears reasonable to think also that the greater part of the traffic was from one point to another point in India.

arguments.claim: Cannot apply Full Bench Formula to Indian operations only due to evidentiary difficulties in allocating receipts, expenditure, capital, working capital, rehabilitation given common vessel use and no demarcation

anchor.surface_text: This becomes painfully clear when we try to apply the Full Bench Formula to the facts of the case. At the threshold of the task, we are faced with the difficulty of ascertaining the profits of the companies for what is called its Indian operations. Assuming that wherever the traffic originates in India the receipts in freights and fares for such traffic should be held to constitute the receipts for the Indian operations, even such an approximation cannot possibly be applied to the allocation of the expenditure.

arguments.claim: No fair hearing as workmen denied access to certain account books

anchor.surface_text: Before we part with these appeals, we have to refer to a complaint vehemently pressed before us by Mr. Chatterjee that there has not been a fair hearing of these cases inasmuch as the workmen or their representatives were not given access to certain account books which they wanted to consult.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n making available to industrial adjudication all relevant papers, including account books which are likely to assist a proper decision of the questio

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected for this case as even access would not enable allocation; but ordinarily employers must provide access subject to s.21

arguments.claim: Employers should ordinarily provide workmen access to relevant account books/papers subject to s.21 Industrial Disputes Act protection; tribunals to allow inspection absent special circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act afford ample protection against disclosure of information which a party may wish to be treated as confidential. Where workmen or their representatives ask for inspection of such papers and account books, it should ordinarily be possible for the employers to comply with the request, subject however to the protection of s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.text: the companies operations in Pakistan and their operations in India form two different units of industrial activity or they are really one

anchor.surface_text: It is unnecessary to discuss in detail the application of the tests mentioned above for deciding whether the companies operations in Pakistan and their operations in India form two different units of industrial activity or they are really one as Mr. Chatterjee, who appeared before us for the appellants, did not seriously contend that they form two different units.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner did not seriously contend otherwise; facts indicate satisfaction of tests such as integrality of functions, interdependence of finance, community of control, management, manpower, and employer treatment as one unit.

holdings.text: on the materials on the present record we are not in a position to apply the Full Bench Formula to a part only of the total operations of the companies in India and Pakistan

anchor.surface_text: All we wish to say is that on the materials on the present record we are not in a position to apply the Full Bench Formula to a part only of the total operations of the companies in India and Pakistan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of evidence for proper allocation of receipts, expenditure, paid-up capital, working capital, and rehabilitation due to common vessel usage without demarcation between Indian and Pakistani operations.

holdings.text: the Labour Appellate Tribunal has rightly rejected the workmen’s claim for bonus for the years, 1949, 1950, 1951 and 1952

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore come to the conclusion that the Labour Appellate Tribunal has rightly rejected the workmens claim for bonus for the years, 1949, 1950, 1951 and 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business is one integrated undertaking with no available surplus on overall basis per Full Bench Formula; impossible to compute surplus for Indian operations alone on record.

holdings.text: even if these account books were made available to the workmen, it would be impossible on the materials on the record to arrive at proper figures for the different items involved in the Full Bench Formula

anchor.surface_text: We think it necessary to examine how far this complaint is justified as, in our opinion, even if these account books were made available to the workmen, it would be impossible on the materials on the record to arrive at proper figures for the different items involved in the Full Bench Formula.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Denial of access did not prejudice as materials still insufficient for allocation required under Full Bench Formula.

holdings.text: Where workmen or their representatives ask for inspection of such papers and account books, it should ordinarily be possible for the employers to comply with the request, subject however to the protection of s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act afford ample protection against disclosure of information which a party may wish to be treated as confidential. Where workmen or their representatives ask for inspection of such papers and account books, it should ordinarily be possible for the employers to comply with the request, subject however to the protection of s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ensures fair hearing in industrial adjudication; s.21 protects confidentiality; tribunal exercises discretion absent special circumstances.
